reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Compelling novel pulls us back to root for Michelangelo!
reviews.reviewText: It was on a trip to Italy with my family when I was 13 years old that I first saw Michelangelo’s sculpture of David. The up-close image is still strong in my mind. David’s serene, serious face, the still before the storm, just before he will hurl his shepherd stones at the bully Goliath. More than 500 years since Michelangelo carved it. The physical form emits glorious beauty and grace even now. Imagine then how this historical novel is compelling, pulling us back to just before—before the statue was carved, before it was even conceived of, before Michelangelo was a master artist and sculptor. As the story unfolds, cleverly told through the eyes and experiences of a rival of Michelangelo, Jacopo Torni, we see the political backdrop, the stresses of daily living, the role artists played in 16th century Italian culture. We see how Michelangelo challenges the status of the older Da Vinci. We root for Michelangelo—and Jacopo too—to attempt to bring an idealized concept into physical form through their art. Author Morelli’s vivid world-building, enriched with careful research, brings us front and center to David’s creation. And now I must book a ticket to see David in person again! Repost of review on Good Reads.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Interesting if not dazzling
reviews.reviewText: Having been impressed by the author's "The Stolen Lady", a very impressive discussion of the creation and later fate of the "Mona Lisa",and having admired the famous sculpture of "David" by Michelangelo, I looked forward to this book. I was somewhat disappointed. Based on the friendship between Michelangelo and Jacopo Torni during the period of the creation of "David", the narration is basically by Jacopo. Jacopo has a major problem of an addiction to gambling and losing, which is holding him back from any success in life at this time. This is OK, but the author, in my opinion, spends too many words in repetitious discussions of his gambling episodes to the point of becoming boring. Once the problem had been identified, it should have been possible to move on to the main story of the creation of the "David". In any event there is a lot of interesting information here about life in Florence in the XVI Century and the creation of the "Giant". One can sort of skim through the gambling stuff and still enjoy the book. The author is worth that effort.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Fascinating glimpse at the life of an art giant
reviews.reviewText: This well written book is based largely on Michelangelo's creation of the celebrated statue of David. While it is partly fictional, there is a great amount of detail on the lives of artists at the time, and their methods and processes. The book paints a vivid picture of life during this period in Italy using a series of characters. I thoroughly enjoyed it and look forward to other books by this author.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Tedious at best
reviews.reviewText: While I enjoyed the other novels by Laura Morelli, this one was very difficult to get through. I appreciate her desire to explore the friendship between Jacapo and Michelangelo, but as a reader I had hoped it was going to be more a story about Michelangelohimself. Therefore, I was disappointed. Also, the long and boring,in some cases descriptions were very tedious and made me want to finish this book much sooner. Not her best!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2022
reviews.reviewText: This book is like opening an art history book and meeting all the artist giants as they were, people plain people!e with extraordinary talents. I may never see the David again, but I know the statue David through this amazing book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good read about one of the world’s great works of art
reviews.reviewText: The author does a great job of telling a story about one of the world’s greatest works of art. Rather than telling it from the point of view of Michelangelo, she tells it from the POV of his friend.Michelangelo was notoriously secretive and solitary in his work,and Morelli uses that to the story’s advantage. The narrator, Jacopo, tells us about the world of Florence in the 16th century,the block of marble used for the David (more interesting than you’d think), how artists were trained, what people were saying about the David, in an interesting story. We see his friendship with the artist Michelangelo, who was irascible, grubby, proud, and often infuriating. This is a pretty accurate view of Michelangelofrom history. I recommend this book for people who like historical fiction and stories about great art/artists.It is a clean book in that there is no swearing, no violence, no sex. Jacopo is a gambler, so there are scenes of taverns, drinking, cards and betting. I would still recommend the book for teensbecause it also shows how Jacopo’s life improves once he givesup those things. But the focus is really on the art.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2022
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed every word on every page of this book. I was a fly on the wall with some of my favorite artists and was there as the greatest sculpture in this world (IMHO) came to be. Thank you, Laura Morelli! Brava!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2021
reviews.reviewText: Although the title "The Giant" refers to Michelangelo's huge marble sculpture of David, the true story is about the friendship of Michelangelo and Jacopo. While Michelangelo is gifted with artistic commissions, his friend, Jacopo, is having lower level artistic success and falls into gambling debt. Additionally, Jacopo feels anxiety and pressure to save money because his parents have left his sister, Lucia, without a dowry to marry. I found myself caught up in the story as Jacopo struggles with his gambling addiction, jealousy of his successful friend and low self esteem. Much of the story is about the lack of communication and the untold secrets that exist within friendships and families. I thoroughly enjoyed reading this story that I believe has deeper levels than may be immediately apparent. Highly recommend this one!

Laura Morelli's books are spellbinding as well as captivating. I really enjoyed reading this tale through the perspective of not Michelangelo, but his friend Jacopo. It was truly an imersive story for me as I felt I was right there, in Italy's 1500s. It felt real and truly inspiring. Great book that I recommend to all art history enthusiasts.
Fue un regalo para mi hija de su cumpleaños, al parecer lo recomiendan mucho, llego a tiempo y en buen estado, espero que lo disfrute

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 9, 2021
reviews.reviewText: Purchased as a prop for David, perfect 💙💛

reviews.reviewTitle: An opening into the world of Michelangelo and his times but there are some surprises
reviews.reviewText: I liked the plot of this book very much. The main character which wasn’t Michelangelo by the way, was carried through his life with personal and psychological challenges against the background the the artisans of Florence. Well crafted and thought out story.

reviews.reviewTitle: >>>>> WE READ TO KNOW WE ARE NOT ALONE <<<<<<<
reviews.reviewText: I AWAITED FOR THIS BOOK FOR SEVERAL WEEKS, WITH GREAT ANTICIPATION OF A GOOD STORY..SORRY TO SAY I WAS DISAPPOINTED.I THOUGHT IT TO BE A STORY OF MICHELANGELO'S LIFE AND HIS ''DAVID'', BUT SADLY THERE IS VERY LITTLE OF WHAT THE TITLE PROMISES.INSTEAD IT IS A WOEFUL ,MISERABLE, DISAPPOINTING LIFE TALE OF HIS ONETIME BEST FRIEND, WHO JUST CAN'T GET HIS LIFE TOGETHER AND IS FOREVER JEALOUS OF MICHELANGELO ACCOMPLISHMENTS.SO, YOU JUST HAVE TO MAKE YOU OWN MIND TO READ IT OR NOT.NOT EVERY BOOK WILL MEET YOU EXPECTATIONS , BUT THERE IS ALWAYS ANOTHER ONE THAT WILL.
